item.title: Beyond Scanning: What Security as Code Really Means
item.description:
Engineering manager: We’ve got security as code! Look, the dashboard shows our scans running in CI.

Me: That’s scanning as code. Not the same thing.

Engineering manager: What’s the difference?

Me: About five years of security incidents you haven’t had yet.

"Adding a scanner to your pipeline is like adding a smoke detector to a building. Useful, but not the same as building with fire-resistant materials in the first place."

Security as Code isn’t about running more scanners automatically. It’s about fundamentally changing how security gets built into systems. Most organizations miss this. They automate detection, declare victory, then wonder why breaches still happen.

item.title: Security as Code: From Checklists to Automation
item.description:
“Here’s the security checklist for the new release.”

“We’re deploying next week. When can we do the review?”

“The review takes two weeks minimum. You scheduled it last month.”

“…we didn’t.”

This is the problem with security checklists. They’re designed for a world where you deploy quarterly. In continuous deployment environments, they’re the wrong tool.

"Security checklists codify knowledge but don't scale. Security as Code codifies requirements into executable tests. Checklists tell you what to check. Code checks it for you, every time."

The evolution from checklists to code isn’t about abandoning security knowledge. It’s about making security verification scale with modern development practices.
